summary: The U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut today entered a final judgment against a New Haven man who was convicted of a felony for his role in a 2005 New Haven double-murder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Connecticut, alleges that, on June 23, 2005, Nadine Crimley and her brother, Ray Caple, were confronted by a third-party witness who claimed to have witnessed Darrell Mayes confessing to the crime. According to the complaint, the witness, who was a high school classmate of Crimley's and Caple's, claimed that he had witnessed Mayes commit the crime and that the witness had been able to spot Mayes on the street. The complaint further alleges that Crimley, Caple and the witness agreed to testify that they had not seen Mayes or Mayes at the time of the murder and that they did not know that Mayes had shot the victim. The court also found that Grogins failed to adequately investigate the reliability of the eyewitness testimony presented at the trial, and that she had failed to provide sufficient evidence to support her decision not to present an alibi defense.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Central District of New York today announced criminal charges against Caple. The SEC filed an emergency action and obtained a temporary restraining order, freezing the assets of the defendants, and ordering the asset freeze and other emergency relief to be placed on the defendants' behalf. The emergency action is being handled by the SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy, which has issued an Investor Alert to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them investments in an investment in a real estate development project.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Connecticut Attorney General's Office, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Connecticut Department of Justice in this matter.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-01221 (March 20, 2005).Â  In a related matter, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action on March 24, 2018, against Attorney James B. Streeto, alleging that he violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks permanent injunctions, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.  On March 26, 2019, the court granted a motion for a preliminary injunction against the defendants from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, ordered the defendants to surrender their guns, and ordered the destruction of any evidence that may have been presented to the court.
